Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: RAPID: Testing High Temperature Subseafloor Tracers and Optical Communication Networks at Axial Seamount Using Available DSV Alvin Bottom Time
Award.AbstractNarration:
This RAPID project involves two different components. The first component relates to a novel, high-temperature glass material which is being developed for future use as a subsurface fluid flow tracer. The second component further develops a new approach to high-speed underwater sensing and wireless communications networks. Both project components are ambitious experiments that progress the NSF mission by providing foundational engineering research with the long-term potential to transform our approach to ocean science, education and policy.

The goal of the first component is to test the stability of a new type of non-toxic, chemically-inert fluorescent glass in hydrothermal vent fluid. If the material can withstand the complex chemical environment of high-temperature vent fluid for an extended duration, it could potentially be used as a tracer for mapping subsurface fluid flow in the future. Such tracer studies will help to address some of the most difficult but fundamental questions we have about the Earth, including: How deep within the Earth does life live? What limits the growth of life in these extreme environments? How large is the subseafloor biosphere, and what role does it play in the carbon cycle? We will test this inert non-toxic material by attaching it to temperature probes and placing the probes in direct contact with high-temperature hydrothermal fluid for 2-3 weeks. We will examine the material before and after vent fluid exposure using fluorescence microscopy, and evaluate any changes in its physical and optical properties.

The goal of the second component is to characterize the range and stability of an optical multi hop sensor network. Sensor networks employ a spatially distributed array of communicating nodes, in which each node collects and transmits data to its neighbors in a web-like fashion. Sensor networks allow scientists to monitor dynamic phenomena over an extended area simultaneously. Optical multi-hop networks will form an important part of the communication backbone for distributed, underwater sensor data collection to help monitor ocean fine-scale phenomena. Such networks can be joined by passing ROVs, AUVs, or other sensors (like those used to monitor the tracers described above) to relay data to each other or onto a cabled observatory or surface buoy for real-time reporting. On this cruise, we will test two optical modem modules deployed multiple times at varying distances apart along a cable. The data will be statistically combined in order to model and plan for future sensor network missions.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This two-component project was focused on the development and testing of two systems for measuring subseafloor fluid flow and optical communication in the deep sea. The first component involved the testing of high-temperature fluorescent tracers to be used in studies of subseafloor fluid flow in zero-age crustal hydrothermal systems. The second component involved the development and testing of Optical Modem Modules (OMMs) to be used for high-speed multi-hop data transfer, and the eventual incorporation of these modems into submarine sensor networks.

Both components of this project have the potential to transform our approach to ocean science. The first component forwards a new technology that will ultimately be used to study sub-surface ecosystems in a variety of environments, including mid-ocean ridges, methane seeps, or terrestrial hydrothermal systems. The second component forwards the development of underwater wireless networked sensor technology. This work serves to validate their function under real world conditions. The OMMs developed through this award address the ocean science community’s need to communicate using low-power at high speeds, interfacing with existing submarine infrastructure such as deployed sensors, moorings, and other mobile or floating platforms.

For the first component of this project we attached inert high temperature microspheres onto three HOBO temperature probes. The microspheres were covalently bound to the probes so that their optical and physical stability could be tested. During R/V Atlantis cruise AT26-17 we placed the coated probes into a high-temperature hydrothermal vent for 30 minutes using the DSV Alvin submersible. Fluorescent micrographs collected before and after the deployment allowed the assessment of changes in their fluorescent response and physical condition of the microspheres. Although the optical tracers were designed for high temperature stability with inert chemistries, the phosphor-loaded SiO2 microspheres dissolved rapidly in the high-temperature hydrothermal fluid. The highly acidic environment, elevated temperature, and the likely presence of catalytic species aided in the acid hydrolysis of the SiO2 matrix and led to the dissolution of the coating. As a result of these tests we are working to develop alternative tracers comprised of TiO2 instead of SiO2. TiO2-based tracers are likely more capable of withstanding the acidic environment of hydrothermal systems.

For the second component of the project we manufactured two OMMs depth-rated to 2 km and two specialized cable clamps to attach them to the ship’s CTD cable. The OMMs were designed for 2-pi emission, 2-watt optical power, and 9600-baud communication. We attached the modems to the CTD cable at several fixed distances during numerous casts. Data collected at each OMM was optically transmitted between the nodes a set number of times based on a graph model of a typical 100-node network, thus emulating links in a multi-hop network. Data for each hop was stored using the on-board flash card within each module in order to estimate the Bit-Error-Rate (BER). We found that the OMMs would have an 8-meter range between hops in waters with an absorption coefficient of 0.3, which is similar to what was measured on average during the cruise. These tests have led to major improvements in the OMM physical layer including the introduction of error correction schemes, occultation awareness, power handling algorithms, and new diode transceiver designs. The next generation modems developed as a result of this project have been measured to have a range of well over 25 meters in surface water with similar optical properties.
